body_html:
I had the same issue, but I notice that tensorflow does not save the file as I define it.
For instance if I save it as:

saver = tf.train.Saver()
save_path = saver.save(sess, 'dropout.ckpt', global_step = 0)

Then there will be no file called "dropout.ckpt"
But there will be a file: "dropout.ckpt-0.meta" . And loading this file successfully loads the tensorflow model. Therefore I will load it as:

new_saver = tf.train.import_meta_graph("dropout.ckpt-0.meta")
new_saver.restore(sess, tf.train.latest_checkpoint('./'))

In your case, I think you are using keras.. In that case you can load and save using:

model.save('my_model.h5') # creates a HDF5 file 'my_model.h5'
del model # deletes the existing model
model = load_model('my_model.h5') # and loads it

body:
I had the same issue, but I notice that tensorflow does not save the file as I define it. 
For instance if I save it as: 

`saver = tf.train.Saver()`
`save_path = saver.save(sess, 'dropout.ckpt', global_step = 0)`
 
Then there will be no file called "dropout.ckpt" 
But there will be a file: "dropout.ckpt-0.meta" . And loading this file successfully loads the tensorflow model. Therefore I will load it as: 

`new_saver = tf.train.import_meta_graph("dropout.ckpt-0.meta")`
`new_saver.restore(sess, tf.train.latest_checkpoint('./'))`

In your case, I think you are using keras.. In that case you can load and save using: 

`model.save('my_model.h5')  # creates a HDF5 file 'my_model.h5'`
`del model  # deletes the existing model`
`model = load_model('my_model.h5') # and loads it`
